newsitem.title: USA: Columbia to build natgas pipeline to NE U.S..
newsitem.headline: Columbia to build natgas pipeline to NE U.S..

text.p: Columbia Gas System Inc Thursday said it planned to build a $600 million natural gas pipeline to carry Canadian natural gas into the U.S. Northeast.

The 380-mile Millennium Pipeline, designed to carry at least 650 million cubic feet a day, would run from the middle of Lake Erie to Westchester County in New York, Columbia Gas officials said at a news briefing.
Columbia has 40 percent interest in the project, and the remaining 60 percent stake will be split among CMS Energy Corp, MCN Energy Group Inc and Westcoast Energy Inc.
Columbia Gas CEO Oliver Richard said he expected the pipeline to begin delivery in time for the 1999 winter heating season.

The new pipeline would connect with the Great Lakes and TransCanada pipeline systems, which Columbia Gas said "would offer the most cost-effective and direct route available for moving western Canadian supply to the Northeast."
Columbia Gas will start taking requests for service on the pipeline this month and plans to file an application to build the pipeline to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission in late summer.

Catherine Abbott, CEO of Columbia Gas Transmissions, said the Millennium Pipeline's biggest advantages over competing pipeline proposals were that it would be built largely over existing rights-of-way and would require only two nominations by customers who want to ship natural gas all the way from low-cost producing areas in western Canada into the high-value eastern U.S. market.
